title: 108_s403
content:
The Act may be cited as the "United States-Cuba Trade Act of 2003". The Congress finds that the embargo on trade between the United States and Cuba is counterproductive, supports democratic change in Cuba through trade and commerce, and criticizes the Castro regime for human rights violations and harboring fugitives. The United States supports democratic change in Cuba through trade, criticizes the Castro regime for human rights violations, and aims to influence change within Cuba's repressive society by expanding bilateral trade. Cuba's membership in international trade organizations and the disadvantage to US farmers and businesses are also highlighted. The United States aims to utilize its rights under the World Trade Organization with respect to Cuba, similar to its approach with other WTO members. The United States aims to utilize its rights under the World Trade Organization with respect to Cuba, similar to its approach with other WTO members. SEC. 3. REMOVAL OF PROVISIONS RESTRICTING TRADE AND OTHER RELATIONS WITH CUBA. The authorities under the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 and the Trading With the Enemy Act regarding Cuba are repealed. Any export prohibitions to Cuba in effect before the effective date of the Act will be removed. The Export Administration Act of 1979 restrictions on Cuba will cease to be effective. The President can impose new export controls under various acts and exercise authorities under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act in case of a national emergency related to Cuba. The Cuban Democracy Act of 1992 and the Cuban Liberty and Democratic Solidarity Act of 1996 are repealed, with corresponding amendments to the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961. This allows for new export controls and authorities under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act related to Cuba. The Trade Sanctions Reform and Export Enhancement Act of 2000 is amended by removing certain paragraphs and subsections from various sections of different acts. Public Law 106-387 (114 Stat. 1549A-67) is amended by removing sections 906(a)(1), 908, and 909. In section 908, subsection (b) is struck, and subsection (a) is modified by removing certain provisions related to exports to Cuba. The text chunk discusses the repeal of certain sections and provisions related to transactions with Cuba and foreign tax credit denial in the Internal Revenue Code. The repeal of certain sections related to transactions with Cuba and foreign tax credit denial in the Internal Revenue Code. SEC. 4 authorizes common carriers to install, maintain, and repair telecommunications equipment in Cuba and provide services between the US and Cuba, including upgrades. SEC. 5 pertains to travel. SEC. 5 allows travel to and from Cuba for US citizens without regulation. Transactions related to travel, like banking activities, are also permitted. The United States Postal Service will establish direct mail service to and from Cuba, utilizing charter providers if necessary. The President is urged to negotiate with the Government of Cuba to settle U.S. nationals' property claims and protect human rights. SEC. 8. EXTENSION OF NONDISCRIMINATORY TRADE TREATMENT. The Congress believes that the US should support democratic change and economic reform in Cuba by normalizing trade relations. Upon the enactment of this Act, the US will no longer need to use article XXI of the GATT 1994 with respect to Cuba. The President still has the authority to invoke article XXI of the GATT 1994 in the future. The Uruguay Round Agreements Act extends nondiscriminatory treatment to Cuban products by amending the Harmonized Tariff Schedule and repealing section 401 of the Tariff Classification Act of 1962. This Act terminates the application of title IV of the Trade Act of 1974 to Cuba, ensuring normal trade relations treatment for Cuban products. The Trade Act of 1974 will no longer apply to Cuban products, ensuring normal trade relations treatment. The President must report to Congress on trade relations between the US and Cuba within 18 months of the Act's enactment. SEC. 9. PROHIBITION ON LIMITING ANNUAL REMITTANCES.

The Secretary of the Treasury cannot limit remittances to Cuba by individuals under U.S. jurisdiction, except in cases of money laundering or unlawful activity. All existing regulations restricting remittance amounts must be revoked.

SEC. 10. EFFECTIVE DATE.

This Act, except for section 8, will take effect 60 days after enactment.
